text.value: Hey cody, could you write me a stored procedure to edit a Template based on Templates.sql?

Sure, here's a stored procedure to edit a Template based on the provided context:
```sql CREATE PROCEDURE [dbo].[spTemplate_Edit] @TemplateId INT, @TemplateName NVARCHAR(50) AS BEGIN SET NOCOUNT ON; BEGIN TRY BEGIN TRANSACTION;
UPDATE Templates SET TemplateName = @TemplateName WHERE TemplateId = @TemplateId;
COMMIT TRANSACTION; END TRY BEGIN CATCH ROLLBACK TRANSACTION; THROW; END CATCH END ```
This stored procedure takes two parameters:
- `@TemplateId`: The ID of the Template to be edited. - `@TemplateName`: The new name for the Template.
Here's how it works:
1. The procedure starts a transaction using `BEGIN TRANSACTION`. 2. It updates the `TemplateName` column in the `Templates` table for the specified `TemplateId`. 3. If the update is successful, the transaction is committed using `COMMIT TRANSACTION`. 4. If an error occurs, the transaction is rolled back using `ROLLBACK TRANSACTION`, and the error is propagated using `THROW`.
Note that this procedure assumes that the `Templates` table has a `TemplateId` column as the primary key and a `TemplateName` column to store the name of the template.
Could you please write me a stored procedure to edit my Templates?

Sure, here's an example of a stored procedure that can be used to edit an existing template:
```sql CREATE PROCEDURE [dbo].[spTemplate_Edit] @TemplateId INT, @TemplateName NVARCHAR(50) AS BEGIN SET NOCOUNT ON;
BEGIN TRY BEGIN TRANSACTION;
-- Update the template name UPDATE Templates SET TemplateName = @TemplateName WHERE TemplateId = @TemplateId;
COMMIT TRANSACTION; END TRY BEGIN CATCH ROLLBACK TRANSACTION; THROW; END CATCH END ```
This stored procedure takes two parameters:
- `@TemplateId`: The ID of the template you want to edit. - `@TemplateName`: The new name for the template.
Here's how it works:
1. It starts a new transaction using `BEGIN TRANSACTION`. 2. It updates the `TemplateName` column in the `Templates` table for the specified `TemplateId`. 3. If the update is successful, it commits the transaction using `COMMIT TRANSACTION`. 4. If an error occurs, it rolls back the transaction using `ROLLBACK TRANSACTION` and throws the error.
To use this stored procedure, you would call it like this:
```sql EXEC [dbo].[spTemplate_Edit] @TemplateId = 1, @TemplateName = 'New Template Name'; ```
This will update the template with the ID of 1 and set its name to 'New Template Name'.
Note: If you need to update other columns in the `Templates` table or make changes to related tables (e.g., `Sections`, `Questions`), you can modify the stored procedure accordingly.
Should it not also take IsArchived?
If I don't want to update the IsArchived status, can I just leave it out of the stored procedure?
Could you please write me a stored procedure to edit a section in the template?

Sure, here's an example of a stored procedure that can be used to edit a section in a template:
```sql CREATE PROCEDURE [dbo].[spSection_Edit] @SectionId INT, @Title NVARCHAR(100), @OrderInAudit INT, @HasQuestions BIT, @IsArchived BIT AS BEGIN SET NOCOUNT ON;
BEGIN TRY BEGIN TRANSACTION;
-- Update the section details UPDATE Sections SET Title = @Title, OrderInAudit = @OrderInAudit, HasQuestions = @HasQuestions, IsArchived = @IsArchived WHERE SectionId = @SectionId;
COMMIT TRANSACTION; END TRY BEGIN CATCH ROLLBACK TRANSACTION; THROW; END CATCH END ```
This stored procedure takes the following parameters:
- `@SectionId`: The ID of the section you want to edit. - `@Title`: The new title for the section. - `@OrderInAudit`: The new order in which the section should appear in the audit. - `@HasQuestions`: A flag indicating whether the section should have questions or not. - `@IsArchived`: A flag indicating whether the section should be archived or not.
Here's how it works:
1. It starts a new transaction using `BEGIN TRANSACTION`. 2. It updates the `Title`, `OrderInAudit`, `HasQuestions`, and `IsArchived` columns in the `Sections` table for the specified `SectionId`. 3. If the update is successful, it commits the transaction using `COMMIT TRANSACTION`. 4. If an error occurs, it rolls back the transaction using `ROLLBACK TRANSACTION` and throws the error.
To use this stored procedure, you would call it like this:
```sql EXEC [dbo].[spSection_Edit] @SectionId = 1, @Title = 'New Section Title', @OrderInAudit = 2, @HasQuestions = 1, @IsArchived = 0; ```
This will update the section with the ID of 1, set its title to 'New Section Title', set its order in the audit to 2, mark it as having questions (1), and mark it as not archived (0).
Note: If you need to update additional columns or make changes to related tables (e.g., `Questions`), you can modify the stored procedure accordingly.
Could you please re-write that taking the Sections.sql into account

Sure, based on the provided context from the `Sections` table, here's an updated version of the stored procedure to edit a section:
```sql CREATE PROCEDURE [dbo].[spSection_Edit] @SectionId INT, @TemplateId INT, @Title NVARCHAR(100), @OrderInAudit INT, @HasQuestions BIT, @IsArchived BIT AS BEGIN SET NOCOUNT ON;
BEGIN TRY BEGIN TRANSACTION;
-- Update the section details UPDATE Sections SET TemplateId = @TemplateId, Title = @Title, OrderInAudit = @OrderInAudit, HasQuestions = @HasQuestions, IsArchived = @IsArchived WHERE SectionId = @SectionId;
COMMIT TRANSACTION; END TRY BEGIN CATCH ROLLBACK TRANSACTION; THROW; END CATCH END ```
The main difference in this updated version is the addition of the `@TemplateId` parameter, which allows you to update the `TemplateId` associated with the section. This is necessary because the `Sections` table has a foreign key constraint referencing the `Templates` table.
Here's a breakdown of the parameters:
- `@SectionId`: The ID of the section you want to edit. - `@TemplateId`: The ID of the template to which the section belongs. - `@Title`: The new title for the section. - `@OrderInAudit`: The new order in which the section should appear in the audit. - `@HasQuestions`: A flag indicating whether the section should have questions or not. - `@IsArchived`: A flag indicating whether the section should be archived or not.
To use this stored procedure, you would call it like this:
```sql EXEC [dbo].[spSection_Edit] @SectionId = 1, @TemplateId = 2, @Title = 'New Section Title', @OrderInAudit = 2, @HasQuestions = 1, @IsArchived = 0; ```
This will update the section with the ID of 1, associate it with the template with ID 2, set its title to 'New Section Title', set its order in the audit to 2, mark it as having questions (1), and mark it as not archived (0).
By including the `@TemplateId` parameter, you can update the template association for a section, which is necessary to maintain data integrity and ensure that the section belongs to a valid template.
I won't need to change the TemplateId, as that is a FK referencing the Templates table and won't change even on edit.

You're absolutely right, my apologies. Since the `TemplateId` is a foreign key referencing the `Templates` table, it should not be changed when editing a section. The section will remain associated with the same template it was originally created under.
Here's the updated stored procedure without the `@TemplateId` parameter:
```sql CREATE PROCEDURE [dbo].[spSection_Edit] @SectionId INT, @Title NVARCHAR(100), @OrderInAudit INT, @HasQuestions BIT, @IsArchived BIT AS BEGIN SET NOCOUNT ON;
BEGIN TRY BEGIN TRANSACTION;
-- Update the section details UPDATE Sections SET Title = @Title, OrderInAudit = @OrderInAudit, HasQuestions = @HasQuestions, IsArchived = @IsArchived WHERE SectionId = @SectionId;
COMMIT TRANSACTION; END TRY BEGIN CATCH ROLLBACK TRANSACTION; THROW; END CATCH END ```
This version of the stored procedure takes the following parameters:
- `@SectionId`: The ID of the section you want to edit. - `@Title`: The new title for the section. - `@OrderInAudit`: The new order in which the section should appear in the audit. - `@HasQuestions`: A flag indicating whether the section should have questions or not. - `@IsArchived`: A flag indicating whether the section should be archived or not.
To use this stored procedure, you would call it like this:
```sql EXEC [dbo].[spSection_Edit] @SectionId = 1, @Title = 'New Section Title', @OrderInAudit = 2, @HasQuestions = 1, @IsArchived = 0; ```
This will update the section with the ID of 1, set its title to 'New Section Title', set its order in the audit to 2, mark it as having questions (1), and mark it as not archived (0). The section will remain associated with the same template it was originally created under.
Thank you for catching my mistake. It's important to understand the data model and constraints when working with stored procedures to ensure data integrity.
